details.purpose: To record the disease classification for an identified infectious disease as part of a disease surveillance investigation.
details.use:
Use to record the disease for an identified infectious disease as part of a disease surveillance investigation, most commonly the final determination at the completion of a case investigation but may also record initial classification as a suspected infection.
Use a separate instance of this archetype to record the conclusion for each suspected 'Index disease'. For example in a fever & rash investigation, considering Measles and Rubella as the potential causes, use one instance of this archetype to record the conclusion, rationale, evidence etc related to Measles, and another to carry the information related to Rubella.

items.items: Classification for an identified infectious disease as part of a disease surveillance investigation.
Classification of the likelihood of the 'Index disease' as causal at the initiation of a case investigation.
Not to be used to record the 'Final classification' after completion of a case investigation.
A case is 'Probable' when common, relevant symptoms and/or signs are exhibited and there is an epidemiological link.
A case is 'Not suspected' if the clinical or laboratory findings do not meet the criteria to suspect disease.
The name of the infectious disease under investigation.
This data element may be redundant if the index disease has been identified elsewhere within a template.
The broad category of the reason for the classification.
For example: lost to follow-up, child of an infected mother.
Narrative description about the reason for the classification.
For example: description of clinical findings and/or conclusive laboratory test results; or alternate diagnosis made.
The category for the cause of infection.
For example: imported, import-related, endemic, vaccine-associated, congenital or unknown.
Additional information required to extend the model with local content or to align with other reference models or formalisms.
For example: local information requirements; or additional metadata to align with FHIR.
The date when this infectious disease investigation classification was last updated.
Additional structured details about the classification.
For example: details about the clinical evidenct confirming or excluding this disease as the cause of the infection
Additional narrative about the classification, not captured in other fields.
Country identified as the (likely or probable) source for an imported or import-related case.
A case is 'Suspected' when common, relevant symptoms and/or signs are exhibited.
Narrative description about the cause of infection.
Exposure occurred outside of the country.
Exposure occurred locally, but is directly associated to an imported case.
Exposure occurred locally, as part of a chain of endemic transmission.
Exposure occurred as an adverse event following exposure to a vaccine.
The exposure event has not been identified.
The category for the source of an endemic case.
For example: household contact, community, or unknown.
Narrative description about the source of an endemic case.
For example: identification of the reservoir or carrier.
Identification of the cause or source of transmission.
Classification of the likelihood of the 'Index disease' as causal after completion of a case investigation.
Not to be used to record the 'Initial classification' at the initiation of a case investigation.

A case is 'Pending' at the completion of an adequate investigation when it is not possible to confirm or discard due to inadequate information, and further information is anticipated. It is usually a temporary classification.

A case is 'Probable' at the completion of an adequate investigation when clinical evidence criteria are met and/or an epidemiological link has been identified, with laboratory test results suggesting causality rather than being conclusive.
A case is 'Laboratory confirmed' at the completion of an adequate investigation when positive laboratory test results confirm the clinical evidence and/or epidemiological link.
A case is 'Discarded' or 'Excluded' at the completion of an adequate investigation due to negative laboratory test results that exclude causality.

A case is 'Inconclusive' at the completion of an adequate investigation when it is not possible to confirm or discard due to inadequate information, and no further information is anticipated. It is not a temporary classification.
A case is 'Clinically confirmed' at the completion of an adequate investigation on the basis of clinical evidence alone.
Assessment of the relationship between the index disease and the death of the individual.
The index disease was directly or indirectly related to the death of the infected individual.
The index disease was not related to the death of the infected individual.
It is unknown if the index disease is related to the death of the individual or not.
